opener.salute: Друг мой сердечный Князь Григорий Александрович.

body.p: Письмы твои от 21 и 24 августа из Дубоссар я получила. Оне меня застали еще немного слабой от спазматической колики, которая продолжалась целые две недели. Теперь я совершенно выздоровела, что приписываю много подушкам с ромашкою, коими Санкт-Петерб[ургский] Митрополит мне советовал обложить около всего тела.

Сказав о себе, теперь буду ответствовать на твои письмы. Чему дивишься, что тебе Бог определил готовить или приготовить для всех, а для тебя ниже переправы не изготовили?Potemkin opened his letter of 21 August with the complaint that upon his arrival at the Dniester River, he found no preparations for his crossing, other than two small ferries, so he was forced to have a bridge built there and on the Pruth. (Ekaterina II i G.A. Potemkin, p. 366, Letter 986.) В тебе в одном более ревности к общему делу и к моей службе, нежели в протчих, и ты же замысловатее. Помоги тебе Бог во всех твоих предприятиях. Я с вашей стороны весьма покойна, ибо прошлогодняя кампания оправдала совершенно мои о тебе мысли и доверенность. Ты же ко мне пишешь часто и подробно et par conséquant je suis sans inquiétude de Votre côte. Что Кобург после победы храбрится, тому не дивлюся: им удача не в привычке. Ils ressemble[nt] en cela aux parvenus, qui sont étonnés de se voir des beaux meubles et qui ne cessent d’en parler et de les admirer.Potemkin attached to his letter of 21 August a report from Prince Cobourg and provided a commentary on it: while Cobourg was so pleased with the victory at Fokshani that he now thought he could take Walachia and Braila, the Austrians had actually already ceded opportunities to take them for fear of losing Khotin. (Ekaterina II i G.A. Potemkin, p. 367, Letter 986.)

Говорят, будто турецкий флот слаб людьми; также, будто Булгаков освобожден, но ни то, ни другое, может статься, несправедливо.Catherine was right: the Russian ambassador in Constantinople, Ya. I. Bulgakov was freed only in November 1789. Желаю тебе от всего сердца преодоления над врагом и надо всеми препятствиями. Пакости поляков вытерпеть должно до времяни.

Я думаю писать к Румянцеву, что его присудствие в Молдавии подает случаи к слухам, моим и общим нашим делам вредным, и что я желаю и требую, чтоб он выехал из Молдавии.See Catherine's letter to Rumyantsev of 8 March 1789. On 21 August, Potemkin mentioned that Rumyantsev was still in the south and commented: 'Как ему не стыдно. Сие не могло производить толков и разглашений, хотя пустых, однако ж вредных' ('He should be ashamed of himself. How could this but produce commentaries and divulgences that, while empty, would nonetheless be harmful'). (Ekaterina II i G.A. Potemkin, p. 367, Letter 986.) Мысли твои по делам теперь ожидаю; ты знаешь мои правила: что полезно – всегда не отрекусь делать, лишь бы сходно было с честью и достоинством Империи.On 21 August, Potemkin promised his thoughts on current affairs, but entreated Catherine not to be angered by what he had to say. Французские суда перестанут ходить к нам: Монморен писал к Шуазелю, чтоб перестал оных пос[ы]лать.On 21 August, Potemkin complained that yet another French ship had arrived at Feodosiya and asked what would come of the apparent French desire to snoop around in all Russian ports. Французские безпокойства переносятся в Брабантию и в Голландию и озабочивают уже Берлинский двор. Услышите вскоре, что они окажутся и в областях прусских, ибо народ гол, а войски чужестранные.

Что ты нашей галерной победе рад был, сие я себе представить могу. Ты увидишь из посланных подробностей, что наша потеря менее, нежели сгоряча думали. Из Гекфорса и Кюменеграда шведы вышли, но по сей час Пушкина ничем принудить не можно было воспользоваться сим случаем, чтоб нанести шведам наивящий вред. Сей мешок нерешимый мне весьма надоел, и воистину он командовать не умеет.

Преобр[аженского] полка капитана Черткова, да прап[орщиков] Сизирева и Терскова приказала послать к тебе, чтоб ты их притравил, либо из полку выгнал.According to V.S. Lopatin, these three Guards officers absented themselves from battle on 13 August 1789, leaving sergeants to command their ships. The sergeants were promoted to sub-lieutenants in the Guards, while the delinquent officers were sent to serve in the army under Potemkin. On 25 March 1791, Potemkin obtained their pardon in recognition of their service at the storming of Izmail. (Ekaterina II i G.A. Potemkin, p. 884.)

За ласку к Платону Александровичу и его брату тебе спасибо. Я не знаю брата, который у вас, а он сам себя ведет так, как только желать можно.In his letter of 21 August, Potemkin said that he would give Nikolay Zubov, currently in Potemkin's army, opportunities to distinguish himself, which he soon accomplished by sending him to St. Petersburg bearing news of victory in the Battle of Rymnik. Potemkin also asked for a description of Valerian Zubov, the youngest brother: 'Описывайте другого: что мешает его отличить, чем сходно' ('Describe the other one: what prevents us from distinguishing him in a suitable way?') (Ekaterina II i G.A. Potemkin, p. 367, Letter 986). Il est d’une humeur égale et très aimable и сердце предоброе и благородное, en un mot, il gagne à être connu.

closer.signed: Adieu, mon Ami, portés Vous bien et soyés assuré de toute mon amitié.

opener.salute: My dear friend Prince Grigory Aleksandrovich.

body.p: I received your letters of 21 and 24 August from Dubossary. They found me a bit weak from my spasmatic colic, which lasted two whole weeks. Now I have made a complete recovery, which I attribute in large measure to the pillows full of camomile, which the Metropolitan of Saint Petersburg recommended that I put around my entire body.

Now that I have told you about myself, I will answer your letters. Why are you surprised that God has determined that you should prepare or make ready for everyone, while they do not even prepare a crossing for you? In you alone there is more zeal to the common cause and to my service, than in the others, and you are more ingenious too. God help you in all your enterprises. I am quite at ease about you, for last years' campaign completely justified my thoughts about you and my confidence. You write to me too often and in detail and as a result I have no concerns about you. I am not surprised that Cobourg is swaggering after his victory: they are not used to success. They are in this respect like upstarts who, astonished to have nice furniture, cannot stop talking about and admiring it.

They say that the Turkish navy is lacking in soldiers, and also that Bulgakov has been freed, but it is possible that neither one nor the other is true. I hope with all my heart that you will overcome the enemy and all obstacles. For the time being we must endure the Poles' mean tricks.

I am thinking of writing to Rumyantsev that his presence in Moldavia is giving rise to rumours that are harmful to my and our common affairs, and that I desire and demand that he leaves Moldavia. I now await your thoughts on affairs. You know my rules: I will not refuse to do whatever is useful, as long as it is compatible with the honour and dignity of the Empire. French ships will stop coming to us: Montmorin wrote to Choiseul that he should stop sending them. The French disorders are spreading into the Brabant and Holland and are already causing concern at the court of Berlin. You will soon hear that they have turned up in the Prussian provinces too, for the people are naked and the troops are foreign.

I can imagine that you were pleased at the victory of our galleys. You will see from the details that have been sent that our losses are lesser than they thought in the heat of things. The Swedes have left Högfors and Kymi, but there was no way for the moment to force Pushkin to take advantage of this opportunity to do more harm to the Swedes. I am thoroughly sick of that sack of indecisiveness, and he truly does not know how to command.
I have ordered that Captain Chertkov and ensigns Sizirev and Terskov of the Preobrazhenskii Regiment be sent to you, so you can train them up or chase them from the regiment.

I thank you for your affection for Platon Aleksandrovich and his brother. I do not know the brother who is with you, but he himself behaves himself as well as can possibly be desired. He is even-tempered and very amiable and a most kind and noble heart. In a word, the more you know him the more you like him.

closer.signed: Farewell, my friend, be well and be assured of all my friendship.
